field_reports.description:
On June 15, starting from 16:10, the Crisis Management Center of the Ministry of Internal Affairs Rescue Service in Aragatsotn Province began receiving reports that due to strong winds, roofs of buildings and structures, cars, and trees had been damaged or toppled at various addresses in the town of Aparan and the Lusagyugh community.

This was reported by Narek Sargsyan, spokesperson for the Ministry of Internal Affairs, on his Facebook page.

According to preliminary data from the Ministry of Health, 4 individuals were injured and have received first aid.

As of 21:00, damages include:

  • Roofs of 43 buildings/structures,

  • 22 passenger vehicles,

  • 3 cargo trucks,

  • 21 fallen trees,

  • 17 damaged electric poles,

  • 3 solar power stations.
field_reports.summary: ARM: Cyclone - 06-2025 - Cyclone: Wind storm in Aragatsotn

contacts.name: Sergey SAHAKYAN
contacts.title: ARCS Head of Disaster Management department

field_reports.description:
On the morning of 11 June 2025, a large gas explosion happened in a multi-story apartment building in Chambarak, Gegharkunik province, Armenia. The explosion caused part of the building to collapse, and the structure has been declared completely destroyed and cannot be restored. The likely cause of the explosion is a gas leak, but the investigation is still ongoing. The force of the blast also damaged nearby buildings, which has made the situation more difficult for people living in the area.

The explosion led to five confirmed deaths. In total, 86 people were injured. Of these, 40 people were hospitalized, including 20 children. The injured are receiving medical care, but many are also dealing with emotional and psychological effects caused by the explosion. The sudden and destructive nature of the incident has brought serious distress to survivors, families of the victims, and the wider community. Altogether, 126 people lost their homes because of the damage to the building. Including people from nearby affected buildings, around 500 individuals have been impacted and have asked for help from local authorities and the Red Cross.

Search and rescue efforts are still ongoing. Specialized teams continue to work at the site to search for victims. At the time of reporting, two people are still missing and are believed to be trapped under the debris. Emergency services remain on the scene, removing debris and carrying out recovery work. The situation is still developing. Assessments are being carried out to better understand both the immediate and longer-term needs of those affected. The main needs include shelter, basic relief items, psychosocial support, and help with recovery.
field_reports.summary: ARM: Other - 06-2025 - GAs explosion in Chambarak, Armenia

results.name: ARM: Other - 06-2025 - GAs explosion in Chambarak, Armenia

field_reports.description:
On February 8, at 04:42 a.m. local time a fire broke out in one of the wooden buildings in Stepanavan city of Lori region Armenia. 16 families (42 persons) affected, 1 woman died. All affected people are placed in local hotels and with relatives. They lost all their homes, belongings and are affected psychologically as well.

https://www.facebook.com/share/p/168gTvkSHQ/?mibextid=wwXIfr

field_reports.description: 1. Displacement and Shelter Needs: o Up to 60,000 people may require emergency shelter or relocation assistance. o High-risk group of 12,000 individuals may face immediate exposure to harm due to their proximity to areas of severe impact. 2. Capacity and Coordination Challenges: o The National Society (ARCS) has requested international assistance, indicating limited resources to handle the disaster alone. o Coordination gaps between ARCS and the government may hinder response efforts, especially if ARCS's Contingency Plan is not aligned with government frameworks. 3. Legal and Administrative Barriers: o Challenges for Syrian-Armenians obtaining Armenian citizenship or visas may delay population movement and expose vulnerable groups to prolonged risks in Aleppo. 4. Healthcare and Essential Services: o Potential strain on Armenia’s healthcare, water, and sanitation infrastructure, particularly in Yerevan and other affected regions, as displaced populations arrive. 5. Weather and Seasonal Constraints: o December weather conditions in Armenia could exacerbate vulnerabilities, particularly for populations arriving from warmer climates without adequate winter resources. 6. Geopolitical and Security Concerns: o Escalation in Syria may hinder organized evacuation efforts, leaving many stranded. o Potential tensions between displaced populations and host communities due to resource competition.

field_reports.affected_pop_centres: Yerevan, Kotayk, Armavir, Ararat, Aragatsotn, Gegharkunik
field_reports.description:
1.	Displacement and Shelter Needs:
o	Up to 60,000 people may require emergency shelter or relocation assistance.
o	High-risk group of 12,000 individuals may face immediate exposure to harm due to their proximity to areas of severe impact.
2.	Capacity and Coordination Challenges:
o	The National Society (ARCS) has requested international assistance, indicating limited resources to handle the disaster alone.
o	Coordination gaps between ARCS and the government may hinder response efforts, especially if ARCS's Contingency Plan is not aligned with government frameworks.
3.	Legal and Administrative Barriers:
o	Challenges for Syrian-Armenians obtaining Armenian citizenship or visas may delay population movement and expose vulnerable groups to prolonged risks in Aleppo.
4.	Healthcare and Essential Services:
o	Potential strain on Armenia’s healthcare, water, and sanitation infrastructure, particularly in Yerevan and other affected regions, as displaced populations arrive.
5.	Weather and Seasonal Constraints:
o	December weather conditions in Armenia could exacerbate vulnerabilities, particularly for populations arriving from warmer climates without adequate winter resources.
6.	Geopolitical and Security Concerns:
o	Escalation in Syria may hinder organized evacuation efforts, leaving many stranded.
o	Potential tensions between displaced populations and host communities due to resource competition.
field_reports.summary: ARM: Population Movement - 12-2024 - Syrian-Armenian Population Movement 2024

5.	Weather and Seasonal Constraints:

field_reports.description:
On May 26, the Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that as a result of the overflow of Debed River emergency situation was created in Northern parts of Armenia, namely in Lori and Tavush regions. As reported, as result of the flood, a 31 km section of the M6 highway between Vanadzor and Alaverdi was flooded, with a portion approximately 50 meters in length collapsing (the highway connects Armenia to Georgia). The flash flooding also forced authorities to close Armenia’s main border crossing with Georgia and suspend rail service between the two countries.

The Ministry reported that bridges over the Debed River have been destroyed and several settlements were cut off. Many residential houses were flooded prompting the evacuation of hundreds of residents from their homes. Lori town of Alaverdi and nearby communities were hit hardest. The Armenian government set up a task force to cope with the natural disaster led by the Minister of Territorial Administration and Infrastructure Gnel Sanosyan. AM PM Nikol Pashinian visited the flooded areas in the afternoon to inspect rescue efforts and damage caused to them.
field_reports.summary: ARM: Flood - 05-2024 - Armenia: Lori's Flash Floods

results.name: ARM: Flood - 05-2024 - Armenia: Lori's Flash Floods

field_reports.description:
On September 19, 2023, hostilities escalated along the line of contact in the Karabakh region, resulting in significant displacement of people to Armenia. Reports indicate incidents involving civilian casualties, including injuries and fatalities, alongside widespread displacement. Over several days, many individuals—predominantly older people, women, and children—relocated from their homes in the affected areas. 

However, despite the cessation of armed conflict, the humanitarian challenges the affected people face persist and continue to grow. Given the ongoing nature of the crisis, humanitarian aid is urgently needed to meet the evolving needs of the affected population.  

Recognizing the dire and evolving humanitarian needs of these displaced populations, various government entities, including the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, Ministry of Internal Affairs, as well as regional and local authorities, initiated collaboration with non-governmental organizations and the civilian population voluntarily to organize initial humanitarian aid efforts. Based on the analysis of the secondary data provided by the governmental agencies, the main primary needs of the affected and internally displaced population have been identified, including the provision of food, non-food items, psychological support, first aid, running hotlines, Restoring Family Links (RFL) services, and essential care materials as well as providing shelter, offering accommodations in hotels, boarding institutions, and the homes of friends, relatives, and host families.  

The NS has been closely engaged with governmental authorities at the highest levels, including the Prime Minister's Administration and local authorities, who have highlighted the pressing need to support privately and publicly owned shelters, housing individuals who will spontaneously arrive from Karabakh.  

In addition to the efforts of national authorities, the Armenian Red Cross Society (ARCS) has played a crucial role in responding to the humanitarian crisis resulting from the conflict. ARCS has actively contributed to establishing and furnishing the registration points in Kormidzor and Sotk localities, enhancing their functionality.

Moreover, ARCS has mobilized 70 staff members and volunteers who have been actively engaged in providing support to governmental agencies. This support includes registering displaced people, providing first aid, psychosocial support (PSS), and Restoring Family Links (RFL) services to the affected population.
field_reports.summary: ARM: Population Movement - 2023-09 - Armenia Population Movement 2023

results.name: Armenia - Population Movement
results.summary:
The Republic of Armenia (RA) has experienced an influx of 101,848 individuals since 24 September 2023, due to the escalation of hostilities in the region, which began on September 19. On 2 October, the Government of Armenia (GoA) officially requested international assistance after activating the Union Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM) on September 29. Out of 97,840 registered (some arriving person have not registered yet), 52% are female, 48% male, 18% over 60, 31% under 18, and 16% have disabilities, as well as 230 are pregnant women among the arrivals. This situation is further exacerbated by the presence of 20,000 people who were displaced during the 2020 and 2022 conflict, still requiring support, placing a significant socio-economic burden on the RA. The recent displacement accounts for 3% of Armenia's total population, posing integration and employment challenges in an already economically strained environment with 26.5% of its overall population living below the poverty line, and an unemployment rate constituting 13%.

The humanitarian consequences of the escalation of hostilities require a comprehensive and sustained response. Governmental entities, non-governmental organizations, and volunteers are working collaboratively to address the pressing needs of the affected population. Recognizing the humanitarian needs, the Government of Armenia (GoA) has been mobilizing national governmental resources, as well as regional and local authorities. The GoA has invited relevant national and international organizations to support the coordination framework. Several inter-agency working groups (e.g., protection, health, CVA, food security) have been established, and are proactively attended by Movement partners.

A vast majority of the people arriving hold Armenian passports/IDs, with authorities stating that access to health and social services is thereby ensured. However, there are concerns that despite the access to essential service in principle, practical access may still be a challenge with regard to service capacities. In addition, many face issues with documentation, leading to the government offering temporary identification assistance.

According to the triangulation of primary data collection efforts and rapid needs assessments carried out by multiple actors, the immediate primary needs of those who left for Armenia include the provision of food, essential household items, psychosocial support, first aid and medical referrals, running helplines, and Restoring Family Links (RFL) services. Maintaining safe shelter is also a clear priority, with arriving people currently being hosted in temporary collective centers, hotels, boarding institutions, and with friends, relatives, and other types of host families. Notably, 48,649 individuals are accommodated in various shelters and settlements currently, while a minimum of 22,650 registered families will require rental support in the following 6 months. The types of accommodation range from private housing, living with host families, in hotels and pensions, to staying in collective centers (such as adapted former educational institutions and sports halls).

The Government of Armenia (GoA) sought the Armenian Red Cross Society’s (ARCS) assistance in registering persons at reception points established in Goris, Kornizor and Vayk, who arrived in the country. The ARCS has therefore played a prominent role from the onset of the immediate response, so far deploying 1,500 dedicated staff and volunteers, for the response operation. Alongside registration, ARCS distributed food and essential household items at reception points in Southern Armenia, with an additional focus on delivering psychological first aid (PFA). At present, with no further relevant influx since the first week of October, ARCS response focusses on the distribution of food and essential household items, as well as mental health and psychological support (MHPSS) assistance, across the country. A needs assessment surveying 5,962 individuals (representing 40,887 members of their households) who reached out to ARCS for assistance, was conducted, revealing pressing requirements in several key areas: There is a significant need for safe shelter and accommodation for those arriving in Armenia, as well as support for host communities. Additionally, immediate needs such as food and essential household items require to be addressed. The expected long-term duration of displacement respectively permanent stay in Armenia, necessitates a focus on transitioning to livelihood assistance and socio-economic integration at early stage. The preference among those affected leans towards cash and voucher assistance (CVA). Furthermore, there is a growing demand for MHPSS, with psychological support ranking as a top priority. Given that 31% of the arrivals are children, addressing their educational needs is a key priority.

field_reports.description: On 15th of June sever hailstorm affected south region of Armenia. Due to the damage of  sewage system and following heavy rain the water accumullated in the villages, roads and bridges have been destroted, water and energy supply systems damaged as well. Overall more than 10 villages with the population number close to 10. 000 have been affected. High water level  became a threat for population; their homes, crops and livestock significantly affected. While local rescue service is doing monitoring of situation and assesment of damaged infrastructure, local administartion started initial assesment of needs of affected population. The same magnitude event affected North part of Armenia in following days, on 18th of June in Gyumri and neighboring villages and in 19th of June in Ijevan and neighboring villages and in 20th in Stepanavan and neighboring villages hailstorm,  heavy rain and flood destroyed roads,  energy and water supply stopped, recsue services started evacuation of people from the blocked roads and local administartion started initial needs assesment.

results.name: ARM: Other - 2023-06 - Hailstorm
results.summary: On 15th of June sever hailstorm affected south region of Armenia. Due to the damage of water drainage system and following heavy rain the water accumullated in the villages, roads and bridges have been destroted, water and energy supply systems damaged as well. High water level also became a threat for population; their homes, crops and livestock significantly affected. While loocal rescue service is doing monitoring of situation and assesment of damaged infrastructure, local administartion started initial assesment of needs of affecrted population.

field_reports.description: Ministry of Emergency situation of Armenia stated the quake hit 16 km from the town of Bavra near the Armenian-Georgian border with a 10km depth. The earthquake measured 6-7 ML at the epicenter. According to the Ministry of Emergency Situations of Armenia earthquake was felt in Tavush, Kotayk, Armavir, Shirak, Lori, Aragatsotn marzes with 4-5 ML intensity and 3-4 points in Yerevan. According to preliminary data, there were no damages reported. NS  branches contacted from HQ of ARCS and based on the information from branches in the regions they do not have damages of infrastructure , injured people and missing.

During and after the conflict escalation in 2020, some 90,000 persons were displaced to Yerevan and ten regions of Armenia. The vast majority among them (around 88%) were women and children, while 22% were older people. UNHCR statistics indicate that around 61,000 individuals have returned since mid-November 2020. Currently, over 20,000 displaced people living in a refugee-like situation are remaining in Armenia, who are unlikely to return to their homes, of whom 11.5% are infants and young children aged 0-59 months, 24% - children aged 5-17 years, 52.5% - adults aged 18-49 and 12% - older people (50+). Approximately 16% of the refugee-like population are persons with disabilities/special needs. Based on the information from Unified Social Service, 20,139 of the mentioned 20,433 displaced people are those who have lost property and are eligible for the Government introduced cash intervention of AMD 25,000 (for men/women and pensioners) and AMD 50,000 (for the people with disabilities in the 1st and 2nd groups and children under 18). Approaching cold season is expected to put the refugee-like population in a dire financial and social situation; on the one hand, due to the increasing expenses associated with heating and the need for winter apparel, and, on the other hand, due to the inflation in the housing market, which in some regions reaches up to 3.3% compared to the prices of November 2020. Based on Statistics Committee "Armstat" data, the refugee-like population are likely to face increased rental expenses in the coming months. Given that the refugee-like population was already facing financial hardships before the winter season, having a hard time covering basic livelihood needs and trying to find a balance between such needs as utility payments, food and clothes, healthcare, and education costs, the imminent winter season will exacerbate those difficulties, precipitating a severe humanitarian crisis. It is also worth noting that while the host communities have played a critical role in welcoming the refugee-like population and providing shelter and livelihood support, their resources have been depleting as well. With the increased expenses associated with the winter season, their support is likely to decrease. The increasing winterization needs of the refugee-like population have been further confirmed by the continuous needs assessment and community engagement efforts of the National Society. Starting from January of this year, 3,518 people were registered for assistance by the Armenian RC's hotline of whom 90% asked for cash assistance, as most of them are renting accommodation and cannot cover all expenses, particularly during the winter season. In combination with the abovementioned factors, the Government support to the most vulnerable refugee-like groups is decreasing. Since the onset of the Conflict Escalation in the fall of 2020, the Government of Armenia, at both the national and local levels, has provided critical support to the new arrivals, including space in communal shelters and hotels and different cash assistance programs. Nevertheless, as the conflict severely impacted the displaced and host community populations in Armenia, with a significant increase in reported physical, social and mental trauma and financial challenges, the Government is increasingly facing difficulties in addressing the growing needs of the refugee-like population. The Government cash assistance program targeting the most vulnerable cohorts within the refugee-like population, including the PWDs, children under 18, pensioners, and economically vulnerable women and men, has not been assisting the target population since November 2021. Consequently, In November 2021, Government appealed to the humanitarian community, including the Armenian RC, to support over 20,000 people living in a refugee-like situation with cash assistance for the coming 3-4 months, to ensure their winterization needs are met. The government appeal was conveyed to the Movement by the Armenian RC in November 2021; notably, mid-November 2021 the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Armenia made a request to the IFRC concerning the assistance required for supporting the winterization of the refugee-like population.

On September 27th early in the morning the ceasefire between in Nagorno-Karabakh was violated leading to number of deaths and wounded people. There is a number of people leaving their homes and moving to Armenia. There is no official information on the number of displaced people available yet. But unofficially these people, mainly women and children are in need of shelter, food, hygiene items, clothes, shoes, etc.
field_reports.summary: Armenia: Response to affected population of Nagorno-Karabakh conflict

results.name: Armenia: Response to affected population of Nagorno-Karabakh conflict
